review_title: Great place to work if you value autonomy > $
job_title: Network Engineer in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Great work/life balance. Great healthcare, especially if you have a family; okay if you're single. Lots of autonomy and freedom/flexibility. Lots of paid vacation/sick time. Good place to learn and build skills.
cons: Prepared to be UNDER paid compared to the industry. Purdue does not and will not attempt to compete with the industry as a whole. If you're looking for $ this isn't the place for you. It will only disappoint you. There is clear intentionality to 'keep you down' here. Purdue will purposefully do things to make you less marketable, so it's harder for you to move on, such as pay for industry certifications. Working here is like being in an abusive relationship. The longer you stay the more entrenched you get and the harder it is to leave it behind. I can't help but feel that is by design. Constantly understaffed. Constant backfilling that never comes through, because they cannot get their hands on qualified talent (because they refuse to pay for qualified talent). Their solution to this is hiring students fresh out of college and egregiously underpaying them until they move on; then rinse, repeat. The most repeated tag line in this department is "it is what it is". Because you have no control over anything and are forced to live with it. All you can do is cope. That's what most of the people working here are doing- coping. Coping with an abusive workplace that never seems to get better.

job_title: Assistant Professor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue University offers an excellent research atmosphere and a strong undercurrent of interdisciplinary collaboration. The graduate student pool is also reasonably strong. The recent research-park developments are cutting edge and allow a strong research focussed curriculum and good grantsmanship. The IT, grants office, and administrative support are strong points. The academic environment is enriching and competent and provides for a rewarding experience. Compensation is reasonable for a school in its ranking and the cost of living in West Lafayette generally, although it hasn't kept pace with recent inflation and home prices. Insurances (except for health insurance) offered at Purdue such as STD, LTD, ADD, Legal, are good.
cons: Common facilities, Renovations, and HR are perhaps some of the weak points. The health insurance is poor for the high price for staff earning >$75K/yr. Compensation is lower than other Big 10 schools such as UIUC, U-Wisconsin-Madison, Wash-U and UMich-AnnArbor which leads to some attrition. Science and humanities pay is lower than engineering and business, regardless of background, which creates some inequality. Overall compensation is adequate for the cost of living in West Lafayette, although this is changing with the recent inflation in home prices in West Lafayette by 50% from 2017 - 2022. Purdue does not provide a home-buying allowance to incoming faculty. Several of the paid benefits and some insurance products (such as paid time off or sick leave/FMLA) do not apply in the summer for academic year employees, which is annoying.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The university is excellent at following established procedures. People are generally friendly.
cons:
As a cost-saving measure, they don't provide supporting items you may need to do your job. For example, I had IT come out and tell me a cable on my university-issued computer was bad and that I needed to go out and buy one. No, I don't think so. I don't care if it's a dollar. That cost is not mine to bear. They're just trying to hack away at any cost-reducing measure they can, which is somewhat admirable in higher education. However, when that comes out of the employees, it's quite a bad practice.

Additionally, when something happens that is unexpected, the university is downright awful about handling it. This is a significant disadvantage to top-down leadership. People feel terrified to go above and beyond to help if they feel like it is against policy. Sometimes, this means that common sense disappears. Things lag behind. The machine seizes and freezes.

pros: There are healthcare benefits. I can afford mental health care (which I need badly, thanks to the work environment and financial stress created by the conditions at Purdue)
cons:
Graduate students are treated more like annoyances than junior colleagues at Purdue. Your wellbeing varies drastically depending on your advisor and their personal feelings about you and how much work you should or should not do. There is no standardized prelim or quals process. Pay is below living wage for the area, but above the cutoff for state and federal assistance programs. The payroll programs used by the university are glitchy and pay is sometimes late or in the wrong amount. 
Grievance redress is lackluster: in many cases, Purdue is happy to protect and shuffle around abusive supervisors. Overall, I would not recommend it.

review_title: heaven for buckpassing and nepotism, but with some good benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The employee benefits, excluding salary, can be quite good. Staff receive something like 300 hours of sick leave per year, and accrue vacation at 22 days per year. Another benefit is 3 personal business days each year. As is common among academic institutions, FMLA benefits are also a plus.
cons:
Probably the biggest con is once you get here, as staff, its hard to get out. There really aren't that many opportunities for advancement or developing skills, unless you want to enter management...and know the right people. Within the past few years, Purdue rolled out a program to try to guide staff on career trajectories. To the best of my knowledge, the program has been a dismal failure, as departments fight for fancy sounding titles that don't allow employees to move or advance anywhere within Purdue.

Purdue University suffers from several problems which one should seriously consider before applying or making the move.
-Did you grow up near West Lafayette, or did you attend Purdue University? If not, skip. There is a strong sense that someone from this region or from Purdue is a better candidate or employee than anyone else around. This feeling flows into hirings, promotions, salary raises, firings, etc. I've had knowledgeable colleagues just completely sidelined and ignored because they weren't from Purdue, or because someone who graduated from Purdue said the opposite thing. This also creates a challenging climate for anyone who has seen things done better elsewhere because the answer to any suggestion is basically that Purdue is the best so why change?
-Purdue is a moderately ranked public R1 institution, yet there is considerable pride and ego here. I've worked at Ivy League institutions and was surprised to find that the sense of strength in reputation and academic programs here rivals those found at more noteworthy places. The dirty secret is that the electrical and computer engineering and aerospace programs are the strongest, while the rest of the university is along for the ride. Along with that, the most open-minded departments are the ones who know they actually are strong programs (engineering).
-The faculty detest Mitch Daniels, the president, but he is probably one of the university's greatest assets. Daniels is a well-known and decorated public figure, and has worked to make the costs of higher education more manageable. Unfortunately, many faculty can't stomach that a non-researcher like Daniels gets the spotlight instead of them.
-Nepotism is a powerful thing here. One way it happens is that among staff, many of them are spouses of faculty, and spousal hires occur more often here than any other institution I've ever worked at. The second way it happens is because of that disproportionate sense of regional and institutional pride: because many of the employees went to school here or grew up here, they tend to hire their friends for plum jobs. This means that if you are an "outsider" you will find yourself with less salary, more work, little chance for promotion, and more constraints on your time so that "insiders" can disappear from the office with their boss.
-The spousal hire situation may make faculty happy, but is toxic for staff. The result is that there are a bunch of unhappy people trying to look busy while not being busy. This results in people not really wanting to resolve issues, not really caring if tasks get done, and playing petty politics. Buck-passing is rife here, among staff and management.
-And why are spouses generally hired at Purdue University? Because of the small size and isolation of the town, there are few potential employers within 50 miles. So another reason why there are many unhappy staff is that there is nowhere else to go.
-In almost every department, there is one real "trooper" who is down in the trenches, diligently working and can be trusted to get things done in a timely and correct manner. Once you identify these individuals, it is a pleasure to work with them. But cherish the time you spend, because soon they disappear.

job_title: Student Office Coordinator in West Lafayette, IN
pros: I have had some wonderful bosses and management that truly care about their staff. My direct coworkers are some of my best friends and I have grown so much.
cons: Upper management really takes advantage of you. I do not work an on call position yet, I am expected to be able to drop everything and come in to work at a moments notice and when I cannot due to classes or previous engagements I am reprimanded. If there is an issue covering a shift at another residence hall that is not my team's direct responsibility and I do not find coverage for it or come in to work it, I am reprimanded. This job is incredibly stressful for very little compensation.

job_title: Custodian in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Other than bolstering my resume for a better job opportunity, none.
cons:
Favoritism/nepotism; cost of living increases are shameful for a university of its size.

Annual pay increases are minimal ($0.20 would be considered generous). Opportunities for promotion are mainly only in title, as the pay increases are not on par with the extra amount of work accompanying them. Work atmosphere is a crapshoot: depending on placement, it can vary widely amongst buildings, shifts, and/or supervisors. I met and had a good working relationship with a few coworkers, some others hostile (through no initiation on my part), and many more not worth remembering. Work-life balance is poor: due to the high turnover rate, many areas remain vacant for months, and skeleton crews will have to pick up the slack. Winter shut down was a blessing, as it was one of the few times I could truly rest and fully focus on my personal interests and hobbies.

Should you decide to work as a custodian here, do not overextend yourself, because the only acknowledgements you will receive will be 1) an unreasonable increase in workload, and 2) reprimanding when you are unable to always and consistently meet these ever-increasing expectations. Your supervisor and/or Crew Chief might not back you up, and they might throw you under the bus just to "better" their own "image"; your coworkers might, instead of working together to achieve a common goal (thoroughly/efficiently completing tasks), actively work against each other, intentionally disrupting the flow. As previously stated, it's a crapshoot, and there obviously is no universal experience when it comes to such a subject. However, my experience was an exercise in frustration, and six years of my time wasted, when I should have long-since ventured to greener pastures. I have finally washed my hands of this place, a decision for which I am most glad.

review_title: Purdue University: a great research university, but in the middle of Indiana.
job_title: Graduate Student in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue University is a research focused school, therefore there are a lot of research opportunities for graduate students, in many different areas. Also, Purdue is well respected nationally and internationally, so having the name of Purdue University on your doctoral diploma can be a good thing. The university does have a lot of internal scholarships and fellowships, particularly in the College of Engineering. They also have professional development workshops on a regular basis. And the health insurance is not too costly. West Lafayette is a decent college town and a more liberal area for that part of Indiana. Indianapolis and Chicago are fairly close drives.
cons: Even though the cost of living in the Lafayette area is pretty low, the average Purdue University graduate student pay is also pretty low. And that pay varies significantly by department. You may end up being a teaching assistant every one of your semesters here, for less than 15,000 a year. (On the other hand, outside scholarships like the National Science Foundation graduate fellowship goes a long way here). Also, Purdue University has a lot of bureaucracy and it is a fairly large school, so sometimes graduate students can feel lost and under appreciated here. The fees for engineering students are the highest in the nation, about 2,500 a year, which can be a significant part of your salary! And finally, the university is in Indiana - no oceans, no mountains, etc, so outdoor sports can be fairly limited.

review_title: Engineering Computer Network - Went from relaxed and fun to weird and difficult quickly
job_title: Assistant Systems Engineer in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Generally good benefits. A good 8-5 with flexible hours. Mostly general help-desk style work, but also more complex and stimulating research problems.

Many of the faculty and staff are wonderful people to work with and have great insight into many topics. This makes supporting these users fun and interesting.

Other than your on call rotations a few times a year you can leave work knowing work stays there.
cons:
Overall you have to play games to succeed (get raises or promotions) or suck up to management. 

The structure is really built up for such a small organization. ECN has 60-70 people across 3-4 groups. With a large percentage in UDS. The number of managers is disproportionate in UDS and becomes a case of too many cooks very quickly. 

You're not rewarded for any technical proficiency or even your ability to interact with users to provide good quality support. Finishing the most tickets is the only metric that matters in the end, even if the items are all super simple.
